item.title: Asian Equities Advance While Treasuries Hold Gains: Markets Wrap
item.description: Asian shares rebounded on increasing risk appetite, putting a regional gauge on course for a sixth consecutive week of gains, and Treasuries steadied as concerns about US fiscal policy eased.
item.dc:creator: Anand Krishnamoorthy

item.title: Borrowers Rush to Sell Yen Bonds as Rising Yields Lure Investors
item.description: Borrowers are finding a silver lining in this week’s surge in Japanese bond yields with higher rates attracting credit investors.
item.dc:creator: Ayai Tomisawa, Takahiko Hyuga

item.title: Linear Capital's Wang on Investment Strategy
item.description: Harry Wang, founder and CEO of Linear Capital, says he sees a complete decoupling between China and the US in technology, and shares more on his investment strategy in the Chinese tech sector. He speaks with Annabelle Droulers on the sidelines of the BEYOND Expo in Macau on "Insights with Haslinda Amin'. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Jane Street Earns $2.3 Billion Riding India Options Trading Wave
item.description: Jane Street Group LLC generated more than $2.3 billion in net revenue from equity derivatives last year in India, where its lucrative trading strategies have sparked a probe by regulators.
item.dc:creator: Chiranjivi Chakraborty, Anto Antony

item.title: Rokid CEO on Business Strategy, Augmented Reality
item.description: Misa Zhu, Co-founder and CEO at Rokid, discusses the company’s business strategy and outlook for augmented reality. He speaks with Haslinda Amin on the sidelines of the “JPMorgan Global China Summit”. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: MiRXES Says China Will Be An Important Market
item.description: MiRXES Co-Founder & CEO Lihan Zhou says the Chinese market is key, as it gives his company the scale to bring down cost. The Singapore-based biotechnology startup made its Hong Kong initial public offering debut. He speaks with Haslinda Amin on "Insight with Haslinda Amin." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Oil Set for Weekly Drop as OPEC+ Weighs Another Big Supply Hike
item.description: Oil headed for its first weekly decline in three, as OPEC+ weighed another bumper production increase that could add supplies into a market already expected to face a glut.
item.dc:creator: Yongchang Chin

media:content.media:description: The Deer Park Complex oil refinery and petrochemical plant, owned by Petroleos Mexicanos (PEMEX), in Houston, Texas, US, on Saturday, March 8, 2025. Some 40% of the crude oil processed at US refineries is imported, and Canada and Mexico, the No. 1 and No. 2 foreign suppliers of oil to the US, respectively, together deliver more than two-thirds of that oil. Photographer: Mark Felix/Bloomberg

item.title: The Cohen Group’s Allen on US-China Relations
item.description: Craig Allen, Senior Counselor at The Cohen Group, discusses the latest developments with US and China relations. He speaks with Haslinda Amin on the sidelines of the “JPMorgan Global China Summit”. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Brazil Walks Back Offshore Tax on Funds After Investor Backlash
item.description: Brazil’s Finance Ministry scrapped plans to tax transfers to offshore funds only hours after the announcement of the levy led to a selloff in the currency.
item.dc:creator: Martha Viotti Beck

item.title: Indian Banks' Loan Growth at the Slowest Pace Since 2022
item.description: Before the trading day starts we bring you a digest of the key news and events that are likely to move markets. Today we look at:
item.dc:creator: Ashutosh Joshi

item.title: China’s Retreat From US Corn Makes It Cheaper for Rest of Asia
item.description: China’s shift away from US corn is benefiting other Asian buyers as cheaper American supply flows into the broader market, shaking up competition for the grain used in animal feed and biofuels.
item.dc:creator: Hallie Gu

item.title: BYD Dealerships Failing Show Financial Pain in China Car Sector
item.description: Car dealership groups in two provinces have gone out of business since last month in China, both of them BYD Co. retailers, evidence of the tough competition in the nation’s auto market and proof that not even selling the country’s No. 1 brand can shield businesses from financial difficulties.
item.dc:creator: Linda Lew

media:content.media:description: A BYD Co. dealership in Beijing. Photographer: Na Bian/Bloomberg

item.title: Gold Heads for Weekly Surge as US Fiscal Concerns Cause Tremors
item.description: Gold headed for the biggest weekly gain in more than a month, as investor concern about the US fiscal deficit boosted the metal’s appeal.
item.dc:creator: Jason Scott, Yihui Xie

media:content.media:description: An employee arranges gold bars at the Italpreziosi SpA precious metals refinery plant in Arezzo, Italy, on Tuesday, May 6, 2025. Gold fell, snapping a two-day advance, as signs of progress on US-China trade talks curbed demand for havens even as military hostilities between India and Pakistan escalated.

item.title: Japanese Stocks Rise on Boost From Weaker Yen, Trade Talks Eyed
item.description: Japanese stocks climbed higher after the yen depreciated following an improvement in the US Purchasing Managers’ Index, prompting buying in export-related sectors. Investors continued to eye the third round of talks between Japan’s trade negotiator Ryosei Akazawa and the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Aya Wagatsuma, Momoka Yokoyama

media:content.media:description: Japanese 10,000 yen, left, and US 100 dollar banknotes arranged for a photograph in Tokyo, Japan, on Friday, May 10, 2024. The Bank of Japan offered to purchase a smaller amount of government bonds in a regular operation on May 13 than it did on April 24 as it seeks to reduce its presence in the country’s debt market. Photographer: Noriko Hayashi/Bloomberg

item.title: 'Vicious, Illegal and Unwise': Summers On Harvard Ban
item.description: Former Treasury Secretary Lawrence Summers speaks on Bloomberg TV about the US ban on foreigners enrolling at Harvard University. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Hong Kong Property Tycoon Fetches $9.3 Million in Wine Auction
item.description: Hong Kong businessman Joseph Lau sold a collection of fine wine for HK$72.9 million ($9.3 million) in an auction, fetching more than $41,000 a bottle for some rare French vintages.
item.dc:creator: Venus Feng

item.title: Top Chinese Drugmaker Hengrui Soars in Hong Kong Trading Debut
item.description: Jiangsu Hengrui Pharmaceuticals Co., China’s largest drugmaker by market value, surged in its trading debut in Hong Kong after raising HK$9.9 billion ($1.3 billion) as listings pick up in the Asian financial hub.
item.dc:creator: Amber Tong

media:content.media:description: The headquarters of Jiangsu Hengrui Pharmaceuticals Co., Ltd in Jiangsu Province.

item.title: Dollar Store to Boost Malaysian IPOs With Year’s Biggest Listing
item.description: Discount-chain Eco-Shop Marketing Bhd. debuts in Malaysia on Friday in a listing that’s set to create a billionaire after the nation’s biggest initial public offering of the year.
item.dc:creator: Ram Anand

media:content.media:description: Customers inside an Eco-Plus Shop outlet in Kuala Lumpur.

item.title: OnlyFans in Talks for Sale at $8 Billion Valuation, Reuters Says
item.description: A Los Angeles investment firm is in discussions to buy out OnlyFans Ltd. in a deal that values the site at $8 billion, Reuters reported.
item.dc:creator: Edwin Chan

media:content.media:description: This photograph taken in Nantes, western France on May 21, 2025, shows the logo of British social network OnlyFans, OF. OnlyFans, which is based in London and which was created in 2016, hosts erotic content, even pornographic, as well as fitness content, musicians and other creators who post regularly online. (Photo by Loic VENANCE / AFP) (Photo by LOIC VENANCE/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Trump Team’s ‘Game of Thrones’ on Venezuela Whiplashes Chevron
item.description: It took barely 24 hours this week for the Trump administration to execute its latest reversal on Venezuela, with the fate of a huge Chevron Corp. venture hanging in the balance as closed-door White House differences broke into the open.
item.dc:creator: Eric Martin, Jennifer A Dlouhy, Andreina Itriago

item.title: Real Sinks as Brazil Taxes Remittances to Shore Up Budget
item.description: Brazil’s currency sold off Thursday as the government announced higher taxes on financial transactions along with a widely anticipated plan to shore up its deteriorating finances.
item.dc:creator: Martha Viotti Beck, Felipe Saturnino

media:content.media:description: A customer withdraws Brazilian real banknotes at an automated teller machine (ATM) in Sao Paulo, Brazil, on Tuesday, Dec. 17, 2024. Brazil's central bank sold more than $3 billion on the spot market Tuesday but failed to stem a currency selloff that is fueling inflation in Latin America's largest economy.

item.title: Lagarde Says International Trade Will Never Be the Same
item.description: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde warned that international trade will be changed forever by the tensions over tariffs, even as the world’s leading economies edge toward some compromises.
item.dc:creator: William Horobin, Erik Hertzberg

media:content.media:description: Christine Lagarde, president of the European Central Bank (ECB), speaks at 'The Transformative Power of AI: Economic Implications and Challenges' conference in Frankfurt, Germany, on Tuesday, April 1, 2025. Euro-area inflation eased further toward the European Central Bank’s 2% target as officials weigh whether or not to continue lowering interest rates.

item.title: Man Accused of Killing Israeli Embassy Staffers Charged
item.description: Interim US Attorney for the District of Columbia Jeanine Pirro says “horrific crimes will not be tolerated” after two Israeli embassy staff members were killed outside the Capital Jewish Museum in Washington, DC.

item.title: Mastercard's Meyer Talks Retail and Travel Trends
item.description: Mastercard Economics Institute Chief Economist Michelle Meyer says retailers are still seeing an engaged consumer and there's no clear evidence yet that tariffs are playing a role in spending on "Bloomberg The Close." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Stocks Lose Steam in Final Minutes of US Trading | Bloomberg: The Close 05/22/2025
item.description: Bloomberg Television brings you the latest news and analysis leading up to the final minutes and seconds before and after the closing bell on Wall Street. Today's guests are Stephen Laipply, BlackRock, Danielle Hale, Realtor.com, John Berger, Sunnova Energy, Michelle Meyer, Mastercard Economics Institute, Katie Roof, Bloomberg News, Heather Brilliant, Diamond Hill, Kristina Campmany, Invesco, Jharonne Martis, LSEG, Amy Oldenburg, Morgan Stanley, Joe Mathieu, Bloomberg News, David Portilla, Davis Polk & Wardwell, Janet Lorin, Bloomberg News. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Former Sunnova CEO Calls End to Tax Credits Un-American
item.description: Former Sunnova Energy CEO John Berger says the US House Republicans’ new version of the tax and spending bill that accelerates the end of incentives for clean energy production is “patently unfair and un-American” on “Bloomberg The Close.”

item.title: Bitcoin Rally Pushes Biggest Token Further Into Record Territory
item.description: Bitcoin surpassed $111,000 for the first time, with traders increasingly bullish on the prospects of the original cryptocurrency amid mounting institutional demand and support from Donald Trump’s administration.
item.dc:creator: Suvashree Ghosh, Sidhartha Shukla

media:content.media:description: A Bitcoin logo inside a cryptocurrency exchange in Barcelona, Spain, on Wednesday, March 9, 2022. Bitcoin dropped back below $40,000, erasing almost all the gains sparked by optimism about U.S. President Joe Biden’s executive order to put more focus on the crypto sector.

item.title: Goldman Accuses 1MDB Banker of ‘Serial Lies’ Ahead of Sentencing
item.description: Goldman Sachs Group Inc. said the banker at the heart of a scandal linked to Malaysia’s 1MDB investment fund engaged in “serial lies” and deception about the fraud, days before he is scheduled to be sentenced.
item.dc:creator: Todd Gillespie, Patricia Hurtado

media:content.media:description: Tim Leissner, former chairman of Southeast Asia for Goldman Sachs Group Inc., center, departs from federal court in the Brooklyn borough of New York, U.S., on Tuesday, Feb. 15, 2022. Ng is accused of conspiring to violate U.S. anti-money-laundering law in a scheme to loot billions from the Malaysian fund known as 1MDB.

item.title: Realtor.com Economist Hale on Home Sales, Mortgage Rates
item.description: Realtor.com Chief Economist Danielle Hale reacts to the drop in US existing-home sales and discusses recent housing market trends on “Bloomberg The Close.” US sales of previously owned homes unexpectedly dropped in April to the slowest pace in seven months.

item.title: Stocks Lose Steam in Final Minutes of US Trading: Markets Wrap
item.description: Wall Street struggled to regain confidence in the wake of a Treasury selloff that shook markets amid fiscal concerns, with stocks dropping in the last stretch of US trading. Bonds and the dollar rose.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth
